journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part E: Journal of Process Mechanical Engineering

title-group.article-title: Design optimization of an accumulator for reducing rotary compressor noise

article-meta.aff: 1School of Mechanical Engineering, Yonsei University, Republic of Korea

author-notes.corresp: J Lee, School of Mechanical Engineering, Yonsei University, Seoul 120-749, Republic of Korea. Email: jleej@yonsei.ac.kr

abstract.p: This article deals with the optimization of an accumulator to reduce rotary compressor noise by maximizing the total transmission loss of an accumulator subjected to constraints on lower bounds of local transmission loss values. Transmission loss of an accumulator is described using the Helmholtz resonator theory to obtain the compressor noise characteristics. An experimental analysis of an accumulator is performed to identify the noise characteristics, and numerical data for use in design optimization are then obtained based on the Helmholtz resonator theory. Dominant design variables are selected via analyses of means, and are verified by back-propagation neural network based causality analysis. The back-propagation neural network is used to establish global approximate meta-models to accommodate the inherent non-linearity and multi-modality in the accumulator model. The genetic algorithm is employed as a global optimizer to find optimized accumulator designs in the context of approximation optimization.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
The reduction of acoustic noise is an important issue in rotary compressor room air conditioners, as are the enhancement of cooling efficiency and the reduction of energy consumption. Air conditioner noise is produced by the combination of a number of factors; the compressor has the greatest effect on the outdoor noise of an air conditioner. Among the noise sources generated by the rotary compressor, the pressure fluctuation of a refrigerant during cylinder compression resonates inside the compressor, and is radiated through the shell or transferred to the room air conditioner.1–3 Muffler and resonator design are important for reducing presure fluctuation. The noise characteristic between the resonant space sound and its resultant fluctuation has been realized.4 In addition, the sound source of the compressor has been identified based on finite element analysis,5 and a radiation/directivity study has been conducted for the compressor noise.6 Noise reduction has been studied through the implementation of a muffler and resonator,7–9 and the fluctuation of the intake muffler has been identified via the numerical analysis technique.10 As shown in Figure 1, an accumulator (a component of the compressor) is a device that first accumulates the low-temperature, low-pressure refrigerant, and then prevents the influx of the liquid refrigerant, so that it has a relatively large cavity volume. Such an accumulator is considered to be a sound path that transfers resonance-induced compressor noise to the air conditioner due to its cavity. The noises produced by accumulators (which represent a delivery path between a compressor and an air conditioner) must be controlled, since accumulators contain large inner cavities and usually generate additional resonance noise during compressor operation. The quantitative analysis of flow inside the accumulator of a rotary compressor has been conducted in a preliminary acoustic study.11 Figure 1.
Rotary compressor and accumulator.

This study deals with the optimal design of the inner cavity structure of an accumulator in order to reduce the noise of a rotary compressor by maximizing the total transmission loss (TS) when R-22 is used as a refrigerant. The experimental analysis of an accumulator is first conducted to determine the noise characteristics, and numerical analysis data for design optimization are then generated based on the Helmholtz resonator theory. Dominant design variables are selected via analysis of means (ANOM), and are verified using back-propagation neural network (BPN) based causality analysis. To accommodate the inherent non-linearity and multi-modality in the accumulator model, the BPN is used to establish global approximate meta-models. The genetic algorithm (GA) is employed as a global optimizer to identify optimized accumulator designs in the context of approximation optimization.

sec.title: Mathematical modelling of the accumulator
sec.p:
The effect of the Helmholtz resonator can be seen in the reinforced plate of an accumulator due to its structure, which consists of a number of holes and a void space, as shown in Figure 2. In this case, the resonant frequency of the Helmholtz resonator is defined as follows12 (1)feff=c2πSVLeff where feff is a resonant frequency that is expressed in terms of a volume V, sectional area S, and the effective length of a neck Leff, and c the speed of sound.13 The acoustic behaviour can be assumed as a plane wave when the tube diameters of an accumulator at the inlet and outlet are less than the wavelength at the specific frequency. In this study, the tube diameters at the inlet and outlet are 12.8 mm, which is shorter than the wavelength in the frequency range of 2 kHz. From this assumption, TL of an accumulator is now defined as follows (2)TL=20log10|PinPoutAinAout| where Pin, Pout and Ain, Aout are pressures and sectional areas at inlet and outlet, respectively. The upper part of an accumulator has a screen to block incoming foreign bodies. While the air conditioner operates, the refrigerant oil and liquid refrigerant fill the lower part of the accumulator. Such a composition allows us to further assume that the upper and lower parts of an accumulator become the plane, making it possible to establish the mathematical modelling of an accumulator. Figure 2.
Schematic of Helmholtz resonator.

The modelling of an accumulator is shown in Figure 3, and the TL value at the inlet or outlet is determined via the four-pole parameter rule, as shown in equation (8). The necessary parameters of sound pressure P and mass flow rate V at the inlet and outlet can also be expressed by the 4-pole parameter based on the specific acoustic impedance ζout at the outlet as follows14 (3){PinVin}=[T11T12T21T22]{PoutVout} (4)T11=(PinPout)atζout→∞ (5)T12=(PinVout)atζout→0 (6)T21=(VinPout)atζout→∞ (7)T22=(VinVout)atζout→0 (8)-1pcTL=20log10[(Y1Y2)12|T11+T12/Y1+Y2T21+(Y2/Y1)T222|] Figure 3.
Acoustic model of accumulator.
The characteristic impedance Y is then expressed in terms of sectional areas Sa,Sp and the speed of sound c as follows (9)Y1=cSa, Y2=cSp

An accumulator has the effect of a Helmholtz resonator due to the use of a baffle; its mathematical schematic is shown in Figure 4, where Sh, Saeff, and t are the neck sectional area, effective sectional area, and neck length of the Helmholtz resonator, respectively. The notations La, Lin, and Lh represent the accumulator length, the in-depth length of a pipe, and the height of a Helmholtz resonator, respectively. Figure 4.
Acoustic model of accumulator including baffle.

The matrix [A] is a transfer function between pipe ends at the inlet, [B] a transfer function matrix associated with a quarter wave pipe, and [C] a transfer function between exits at the end. In equation (9), k is a wave number. The impedance at the end of a tube Zb and the air-gap impedance of the Helmholtz resonator Zh can be expressed as equations (11) and (12), respectively. (11)Zb=Zh+jcSaefftankLrcSaeff+jZhtankLr (12)Zh=(cSh-Sp){0.0072+jk(t+0.75D)} -j(cSa-Sp)cotkLh where the value 0.0072 is a loss due to the wall, and the value 0.75 is a compensation of the neck length. The effective diameter of a resonator hall D is given as follows (13)D=2Sh-Spπ

sec.title: Experimental and numerical analysis
sec.p:
In this study, the baseline accumulator noise can be experimentally identified in terms of sound pressure level (SPL) using a sound measurement system in an anechoic room, as shown in Figure 5(a) and (b). For the experiment, the compressor is located in an anechoic room while an automatically controlled sound measurement system that consists of an evaporator, condenser, and expansion valve is set up outside the anechoic room. The sound is measured under the American Society of Heating, Refrigerating, and Air-Conditioning Engineers (ASHRAE-T) conditions, as shown in Table 1. The measurement is conducted using PULSE,16 and the A-weighting SPL results are obtained at a distance of 0.9 m from the compressor. Figure 5.
Experimental process: (a) sound measurement system and (b) noise testing in anechoic room. Table 1.
ASHRAE-T conditions.
Refrigerant R-22
Suction pressure 5.35 ± 0.20 kg/cm2 G
Discharge pressure 20.85 ± 0.20 kg/cm2 G
Suction temperature 35.0 ± 2.0°C
ASHRAE-T: American Society of Heating, Refrigerating, and Air-Conditioning Engineers.

Experimentally measured SPLs for a baseline design are shown in Figure 6(a), wherein the noise due to the accumulator is detected in zones A, B, and C. When an accumulator is equipped, the compressor noise is increased in such three local zones, compared to other zones. The high-frequency noise over 1.5 kHz can be isolated via felt and/or cabinet, but the low-frequency noise is transmitted, especially in zones A, B, and C. Figure 6.
Sound quality of baseline rotary compressor and accumulator: (a) SPL by experiment and (b) computed TL of accumulator. SPL: sound pressure level; TL: transmission loss.

Thus, the noise reduction of an accumulator can be achieved by maximizing the TL in the three zones. A computer program has been developed to calculate the TL based on the Helmholtz resonator theory, as described in Chapter 2. The computed TL of a baseline accumulator is presented in Figure 6(b); the baseline shows that higher values of TL are found outside of zones A, B, and C. The formal optimization method plays an important role in improving the accumulator noise.

sec.title: Design formulation
sec.p: Based on the experimental noise characteristics of TL described in the earlier section, the formal optimization statement for the accumulator design is written as follows (14)Maximize TL(xi)Total Subject to TL(xi)zone_A≥63dB
3≤x1≤7 for number of holes
5.0≤x2≤15.0 for hole diameter (unit: mm)
195.0≤x3≤205.0 for shell length (unit: mm)
145.0≤x4≤165.0 for pipe length (unit: mm)
50.0≤x5≤110.0 for baffle height (unit: mm)
1.0≤x6≤2.5 for baffle thickness (unit: mm)

The objective function is chosen as TL_total such that the sum of the TL values over the frequency range should be maximized. Local TL values of TL_A, TL_B, and TL_C measured at the accumulator are obtained by applying the Hanning window, as shown in Figure 6(b). They are considered inequality constraints; each of the local TL values should be greater than its currently used baseline noise conditions of 63, 61, and 66 dB. In this study, a total of six candidate design parameters that correspond to the size and dimensions of an accumulator’s inner components are selected based on the TL and the Helmholtz resonator theory; these parameters are presented in Figure 7. Figure 7.
Candidates design parameters.

The design analysis is conducted prior to formal optimization to examine the behaviour of TL. It is important to determine the inherent non-linearity of the analysis model, since this result provides a guideline regarding what kind of optimization method would be advantageous. Figure 8 presents a number of response contours of TL_total. TL_total is highly non-linear and even multi-modal in terms of design variables, which necessitates more rational global optimization strategies such as function-value-based approximate meta-models and optimizers rather than sensitivity-based non-linear mathematical programming methods. Figure 8.
Response contours of total TL: (a) TL_total vs. number of holes and shell length, (b) TL_total vs. number of holes and baffle thickness, (c) TL_total vs. hole diameter and pipe length, and (d) TL_total vs. shell length and baffle thickness. TL: transmission loss.

sec.title: Analysis of means
sec.p:
A sensitivity analysis between six candidate parameters and four responses (TL_total, TL_A, TL_B, and TL_C) is carried out to determine the major design variables for use in the formal optimization of an accumulator. Using three-level parameter variation, as shown in Table 2, the L27 orthogonal array-based DOE data are generated to evaluate the analysis of means.17 The parameter sensitivity using ANOM is shown in Table 3 and Figure 9. The analysis of means facilitates the extraction of four dominant design variables out of a total of six candidate design parameters, which implies that such design variables dominantly affect the accumulator noise to maximize the TL. Figure 9.
ANOM-based sensitivity analysis: (a) TL_total, (b) TL_A, (c) TL_B, and (d) TL_C. ANOM: analysis of means. Table 2.
Design variables and their levels in DOE.
Level Design variable
x1, Number of holes x2, Hole diameter (mm) x3, Shell length (mm) x4, Pipe length (mm) x5, Baffle height (mm) x6, Baffle thickness (mm)
1 3 5.0 195.0 145.0 50.0 1.0
2 5 10.0 200.0 155.0 80.0 1.5
3 7 15.0 205.0 165.0 110.0 2.5
Table 3.
Analysis of means.
Δ = |Max–Min| Design variable
Number of holes Hole diameter Shell length Pipe length Baffle height Baffle thickness
TL_total 2.53 3.23 0.56 0.74 4.87 2.77
TL_A 3.96 6.89 1.26 2.07 8.19 1.03
TL_B 1.43 1.24 0.61 0.66 5.97 1.20
TL_C 2.76 1.53 2.01 2.42 8.66 3.90

sec.title: Process of approximate optimization
sec.p: Since the analysis model of an accumulator shows its non-linear and multi-modal behaviours, the rational optimization process should be considered. To accommodate the inherent non-linearity and multi-modality in the accumulator analysis, this study adopts the BPN18,19 to establish global approximate meta-models, and employs the GA20,21 as a global optimizer to determine an optimal accumulator design.

The optimization process used to reduce accumulator-induced noise is as follows
Helmholtz resonator theory-based noise analysis data are generated at random to be used for both training and testing the BPN.
The BPN meta-model is established with the training data. A well-trained BPN can finally be obtained when the averaged relative error of the testing data is normally within 5%.
Global approximate optimization is conducted by connecting the GA with the BPN meta-model.
Once the GA-based approximate optimal designs are determined, validate the design solutions by their noise calculation data.

A well-trained BPN can be further utilized to realize the causality relation between input variables and output responses, and such a BPN-based causality result is comparable to that obtained from a design of experiments (DOE) based analysis of means. The BPN requires randomly generated training data over the entire design space, whereas the ANOM uses a finite number of levels of design parameters. Therefore, it can be said that the BPN-based causality analysis qualitatively provides the global sensitivity information, and the ANOM quantitatively provides the local sensitivity data. The subsequent section discusses the theory of BPN-based causality analysis in greater detail.

sec.title: BPN-based causality analysis
sec.p: The trained interconnection weights are obtained by learning the BPN, which can approximate the input and output data, and identify the causality relation between input parameter and output responses. Such a causality relation qualitatively provides the global sensitivity information over the entire design space.22,23 Consider the strengths of interconnections between neurons of the various layers of a well-trained BPN. For a network with a single hidden layer of neurons, the interconnection weights between the input and hidden layers and between the hidden and output layers are denoted as wij and ujk, respectively. If the magnitude of interconnection weights is used to determine flow paths of information, then the signal fraction fj received at the jth hidden layer neuron (which can be attributed to the ith input neuron) is given as follows (15)Sj=∑i=1N|wij| (16)fj=|wij|Sj where Sj is the sum of the magnitude of weights between all input layer neurons and the jth neuron of the hidden layer. If the output signal is that of a node k of the output layer, then the signal from the jth hidden layer node is further multiplied by |ujk|, and the sum of all such signals through the different neurons J in the hidden layer can be written as follows (17)ηik=∑j=1J|wij|·|ujk|Sj

If the sum of all ηik values taken over all input layer neurons is denoted by Θk, then the fraction of an output weight that is attributable to the ith input neuron can be expressed as the elements tik of a transition matrix [T] as follows (18)Θk=∑i=1Nηik (19)tik=ηikΘk
This can be further normalized in the following manner (20)t¯ik=tik∑i=1Ntik

The elements of this matrix show the contribution of the ith input to the kth output. Note that the above operation is equivalent to a matrix multiplication of normalized or partitioned interconnection weight matrices of successive layers taken in order; the extension to a multiple hidden layer network is straightforward. By inspecting a particular column of this matrix (e.g. the kth column), the influence of each input component on the kth output component can be qualitatively assessed. Since the sum of all elements in a column is unity, this influence is represented by a fractional quantity, and allows for easy identification of dominant input variables. Thus, this transition is referred to as the absolute causality analysis matrix. Note that a change in the transition matrix resulting from a change in size of the training set can be used to determine whether an adequate number of training patterns has been considered.

sec.title: BPN-based analysis
sec.p: A total of 150 data points are randomly generated based on the Helmholtz resonator theory; 100 data points are used to train the BPN, and the remaining 50 are used to test the well-trained BPN. The BPN architecture used in this study is 6 × 8 × 4, where each integer value corresponds to the number of nodes in the input layer (six input design parameters), hidden layer, and output layer (four output responses), respectively. In this study, the sigmoid function is used as an activation function for all neurons as follows (21)Zj=f(zj)=11+exp(-σzj) where the parameter σ is the slope of a sigmoid function that results in a well-trained BPN. The weight update rule is based on the following traditional equation (22)wij(t+1)=wij(t)+α·Δwij(t) where t is an iteration counter and α the learning rate that also results in successful BPN training. The slope of a sigmoid function is σ = 0.5. In training the BPN, the learning rate is α = 0.7, and the convergence criterion for training of |wij(t+1)-wij(t)|≤ɛ is ɛ=0.03.

The BPN-based causality analysis facilitates the identification of the dominant and sensitive design variables by the output responses. The result of BPN-based causality analysis is shown in Table 4, and this can be compared with the result of ANOM in Table 3; the extraction of four dominant design variables is the same even though their ranks are slightly different. We conclude that the BPN-based causality analysis produces a result consistent with the ANOM-based sensitivity analysis, and the four design variables (number of holes, hole diameter, baffle height, and baffle thickness) turn out to be dominant parameters affecting the noise reduction of an accumulator. Table 4.
BPN-based causality analysis.
Design variable Sum (%)
Number of holes (%) Hole diameter (%) Shell length (%) Pipe length (%) Baffle height (%) Baffle thickness (%)
TL_total 18 23 10 6 28 15 100
TL_A 19 30 7 12 26 6 100
TL_B 13 13 8 12 47 7 100
TL_C 13 16 10 10 31 20 100
BPN: back-propagation neural network.

The root mean square error (RMSE) for 50 testing data is demonstrated as shown in Table 5, where 6-DV represents the use of all six design variables and 4-DV denotes the use of the four major design variables extracted from the sensitivity analysis. Two cases of 6-DV and 4-DV have RMSE values less than 0.2, which corresponds to a relative error of 0.27 %; this is deemed to be the acceptable level of approximation error, and is applicable to the approximate optimization. Figure 10(a) and (b) shows the deviations of the total TL TL_total between the actual and predicted data according to the number of design variables. Figure 10.
Test data approximation of TL_total: (a) 6-DV case and (b) 4-DV case. Table 5.
RMSEs of approximate output responses.
RMSE
TL_total TL_A TL_B TL_C
Approximation with 6-DV 0.105 0.022 0.163 0.115
Approximation with 4-DV 0.068 0.029 0.122 0.124
RMSE: root mean square error.

sec.title: Approximate optimization results
sec.p: We now compare two aspects of the different optimization methods; one is the problem of six candidate design parameters versus four dominant design variables, and the other is the approximate optimization problem with the direct (i.e. non-approximate) optimization problem. The latter is related to how accurately the BPN meta-model produces actual near-optimal solutions, and the former is about the practical contribution of the dominant design variables to the engineering optimization. That is, the direct optimization with six design parameters is the closest to the actual design model, while the approximate optimization with four design variables is the simplest design model. As a global optimizer, the GA requires a number of control parameters as follows: the cross-over rate is Pc = 0.9 and the mutation rate is Pm = 0.01, with the number of populations NPOP = 50 and the number of generations NGEN = 100.

A total of four different optimized design solutions and their corresponding output results are shown in Tables 6 and 7, respectively. Improved TL_total values by each of the optimization strategies are also presented in Figure 11. Note that the design variables shell length and pipe length have constant values in their initial designs in for the problem of four design variables, which means that they are considered as fixed problem parameters. The convergence of optimized solutions in Table 6 is compatible with the trend of ANOM results, as shown in Figure 9. For all optimization strategies, the number of holes and the hole diameter converged to level-1 values of 3 and 5 mm, respectively, and these values are coincident with the ANOM result in Figure 9. All the optimization strategies locate the maximum TL at the baffle height (50 mm), whereas the ANOM presents its maximum at the level-3 of 110 mm, which does not satisfy the constraint of TL_A. All the design variables except for baffle thickness converged to optimized solutions within a relative approximation error of 2 % while satisfying three constraint conditions. That is, most of the design variables have similar design solutions regardless of the optimization strategy, as shown in Table 6. It is notable that the optimized values of baffle thickness range from 1.0 and 1.9, since its design space is a relatively small 1.5 mm (=2.5 − 1.0); the convergence of the baffle thickness seems to be incomplete compared to other design variables. Approximate optimal solutions are validated with their noise calculation data, as shown in Table 7, wherein approximate optimal objective function values are mostly similar to their calculated values, and all approximate and actual constraint values are located at feasible solutions, satisfying the constraint conditions. However, the slight deviation between the use of 6-DV and 4-DV is detected in zone-C, where an approximate 4-DV result of 73.3 dB is more exaggerated than an approximate 6-DV result of 70.2 dB, as shown in Figure 11 and Table 7. Figure 11.
Total TL values of optimized accumulators. TL: transmission loss. Table 6.
Comparison of optimized design solutions.
Design variable
Number of holes Hole diameter Shell length Pipe length Baffle height Baffle thickness
Initial 5 10.00 200.0 155.0 80.0 1.5
Approximate with 6-DV 3 5.03 200.2 157.8 50.0 1.6
Approximate with 4-DV 3 5.04 200.0 155.0 50.0 1.9
Direct with 6-DV 3 5.10 201.9 156.9 50.1 1.0
Direct with 4-DV 3 5.07 200.0 155.0 51.0 1.0
Table 7.
Comparison of optimized output results.
Objective Constraints
TL_total TL_A ≥ 63 dB TL_B ≥ 61 dB TL_C ≥ 66 dB
Initial 73.3 62.4 60.9 66.3
Approximate with 6-DV Approximation 82.9 77.7 62.8 70.2
Actual 81.7 76.3 61.8 72.8
Approximate with 4-DV Approximation 82.2 76.9 61.7 73.3
Actual 81.8 76.5 61.8 72.8
Direct with 6-DV 82.1 76.2 61.8 74.0
Direct with 4-DV 81.7 76.5 61.7 72.6

From the comparative study performed in this study, it is known that non-dominant design parameters do not affect the optimization results, and are even removable from the set of design variables. Well-trained BPN is applicable to replace the actual analysis model, and provides a guideline for causality relations between input parameters and output responses that extract the major and dominant design variables in the context of practical engineering optimization. The direct optimization with a total of six design parameters enhances the total TL by about 8.7 dB, and detects the remarkable noise reduction in zones A and C. Such optimized TL with respect to the frequency is compared with the initial design as shown in Figure 12, wherein the total TL is improved, and three local TL values are satisfied. Figure 12.
Comparison of total TL values. TL: transmission loss.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study optimizes an accumulator to reduce noise from a rotary compressor for use in air conditioning systems. The noise characteristics with and without the accumulator are experimentally identified in terms of SPL, and the optimization statement is formulated such that the total TL is maximized subject to constraints on the lower bounds of three local TL. The dominant design variables are obtained via the DOE-based analysis of means, and they are verified with causality analysis based on the BPN. To accommodate the inherent non-linearity in the analysis model, the BPN is used to establish global approximate meta-models, and the GA is employed as a global optimizer to find optimized accumulator designs. Once the GA-based approximate optimal designs are found, such design solutions are validated with the calculated noise data. Through the approximate optimization in this study, the TL of 8.7 dB is increased under the satisfaction of lower bounds on three local TL values, compared to the baseline accumulator under the approximation error of 1.6 % whose actual value corresponds to about 1.2 dB.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
